Review Title: Third class is recommended. Manafort, but only after an hour or two ride.
Review Text: The first and second classes are scrambled and it is difficult to ride while watching the schedule on site. Riding on tour has no travel sentiment in a chartered tour vehicle. Reservations are not required for the third class, and you can interact with local people. The old lady across the street had always cared about getting off at the station, and the young woman next door gave us her window seat. With peanuts. On the last day of the itinerary, with no particular plans in Nuwara Eliya, consult the driver and take the 9.10am train from the nearest Nanu Oya to Hatton, almost tea plantation view. Some of them have an altitude. Then we drove to the airport. It was about 30 minutes late on the day, but if you don't have time, you can't. The third-class toilets don't have the courage to use them, but you can endure them for just over an hour.
I am from Sri Lanka and work as a Tourist chauffeur guide for many years for many leading Travel agency in Sri Lanka Sunway Holidays pvt Ltd Negambo Esna Holidays Colombo Suffron island Tour Blue

Review Title: A station that begs a stationing -for few hours.
Review Text: This is fascinating stopover for a day, particularly for a railway or tea country enthusiast. The long platforms of the recently refurbished station has the amenities needed and a good 2 hours between train times[ my suggestion is to take the 4am train leaving Kandy and reaching Nanuoya by 1030am, and take the return train Podi Manike that normally reach the Nanuoya station by 1230pm. The 2 hour gap will give a visitor sufficient time to take in the atmosphere of the surrounding .Either side of the track, particulalry in the direction of Parakramapura is lined with some of the best tea growth in the hill country.On the other side You could be witness to two fascinating waterfalls by literally standing over them atop the century old cast iron bridges which themselves are an attraction. With all of them situated very close to station, you might as well find time even for a decent meal before the arrival of Podimenike.

We travelled from Nanu-Oya to Demodara which is a 3 hour ride through the mountains, absolutely beautiful. The reason why we didn‚Äôt get off at Ella is because we wanted to see the 9 arch bridge from aboard the train rather than walking 2km along the track. Nice station, good toilet facilities.
Definitely a vintage train, would absolutely recommend the sightseeing compartment. The ride was pretty smooth and very pretty.

There's a huge underhand racket going on at Nanu Oya station for train tickets and this needs to be cleaned up by the Railways or the relevant tourist authorities. My holiday to Sri Lanka was excellent and would have been complete if I got to travel on the 1st Class Observation car for a few stations either from Nanu Oya to Pattipola or Nanu Oya to Thalawakelle. The guy who served me at the station counter (Pramuka) found a seat for me to travel from Nanu Oya to Thalawakelle.  When I went to pay Rs2,000 for the ticket he didn't want to issue the ticket.  Instead he asked me to complete a form where I had to fill the intended travel date, where I wanted to go and my passport details.  He promised to call me that evening before 9.30pm but I never heard back from him.  I needed to know  whether he was able to secure a ticket for me so that I could plan my next day accordingly. Not sure why he didn't want to sell the available ticket to me to travel to Thalawakelle instead.  He initially thought that I was an agent trying to secure a seat.  I then told him that I am a passenger and not an agent. I am very disappointed that I wasn't able to do this train trip.  If I paid black market rates to buy a ticket I could have easily secured a seat. Something needs to be done to clean this mess so that the visitors get a fair chance to enjoy the train journey in Sri Lanka.

Sweet little roadway station. Very clean and tidy.  A little chaotic getting tickets for the next train but doable!  Best to check at railway station for train times!  We caught the 11.10am and had 2nd class  u reserved but got a seat.  Fab train journey. Highly recommended.  We paid usual local fare not hyped prices by travel agents!

Review Title: Horrible nanu oya station eve teasing on tourists
Review Text: Beware of drunk drivers especially at night,had a terrible experience,where the lkr railway was delayed due to engine overheat later, harrasment by the taxi driver / tuk tuk.They were fully drunk misbehaved with my wife.. There should be awareness that even the station master on hearing us,went by locking his cabin...please ladies be safe if you are planning to reach Nanu oya station at night..
Nanuoya is famous for its railway station of Sri Lanka's railway Hill Country main line and it is the closest railway station to the Nuwara Eliya.

Review Title: Only visit if you are catching the train
Review Text: You would only visit here if you were catching the train. Nice enough station that was somewhat chaotic when the train arrived

I have mixed feelings about this place. On one hand, it looks great. The place has this atmosphere of a historical building, and most of the things, such as timetables, are old and original. But on the other hand, also the quality of whatever service gives an impression that it's very old and not updated. The train that I was taking with my boyfriend had delay 2 hours. Later I have learned that this is normal. We were standing there for 2 hours outside, since the place is totally crowded. The waiting place inside of the building is for people with the tickets for the 1st class only, which we didn't have. At the same time, there are also toilets at the same waiting room. I didn't see anyone checking if the travelers have the 1st class tickets, but then I also didn't get why the station made the waiting room with the toilets only for the 1st class. Like only the 1st class passengers needed to pee.
A place you should see and come out from the station to see the nuwaraeliya. From here only you can go for a good view to Ella or towards kandy. Very special to everyone.

Closest Railway Station to Nuwara Eliya Town. If you are planing your trip to Nuwara Eliya by Train Nanu Oya is the ideal station to get down. Even though Pattipola and Ambewela stations situated in Nuwara Eliya bound Nanu Oya station is nearest station from Nuwara Eliya town. Around 5-6 Km to Nuwara Eliya. There are local buses runs through this town (Nanu -Oya)  or else you can hire a Tuk from this station. Station located in the Nanu Oya town. There is a eye catching water fall located near this station.

If you want to enjoy the experience get the first class tickets. We got 2nd class and it was a disaster. We were standing up most of the trip and there were too much people, because of that the ride was miserable.

We want to see world senic train ride so we start it from Nanu oya to Ella in the morning time .but at the morning all seat there book so we  ride at the evening .this station is good spot to move to Nuwara Eliya and also Ella ,enjoy train trip

Is there no room for manners during Covid? I tried to purchase two first class tickets and was rudely informed that they didn‚Äôt have change for my 5000 lkr note. While I expect this scenario from tuk tuk drivers, I don‚Äôt expect it from a train station where I saw at least 50 people waiting for a train. I opted for the second class option which turned out to be okay. But the rude behaviour of the ticket agents was unacceptable. Only to add insult to injury, the platform guy who looked like a cop scolded my friend in Sinhalese to tell me to wear my mask properly. I was later informed that this individual used profanity on my friend. Highly uncalled for. There is no excuse for rudeness such as this. Other than that,the train ride was lovely

This train station services nearby Nuwara Eliya. It would not be a complicated thing to buy tickets, signs readily available for the classes of service. An overpass afforded views of incoming trains. It otherwise is functional as a basic train station.

Travelling on the train from Kandy was a wanted and anticipated "experience" for our Sri Lanka holiday.  The train trip itself was slow and the ride quite rough in places - but quite acceptable for us. Interesting scenery along the way. We travelled 2nd class - reserved. The train toilets were not good - one squat {with no paper} .. and possibly a western toilet in the inexplicably locked room opposite.  But that was not a big upset. But upon arrival at Nanu Oya we were will in need of the station rest rooms and queued with others for the Foreigners Restrooms. However these were quite disgusting!  No running water for the toilet or wash basin. Toilet blocked with paper and faeces and no way to address this.  No handle on the washbasin tap, toilet door would not shut properly. Several indications that these were not new problems. The biggest upset was when we reported this to station staff ( via a local tour guide) .  They stated that they did not accept that there was anything wrong. And clearly they were not going to make any attempt to correct it! This area of Sri Lanka has become a significant tourist drawcard - and this was they way they treated international tourists!  Shame!
The station has a special bathroom for foreign tourists. Great idea, but the said bathroom is missing running water or door lock.

A very beautiful train journey to Ella from Nanu Oya. Mist, rains, and beautiful greens. My kids enjoyed it thoroughly so did we. A special mention to my tour operator " My Ceylon Trip, to have arranged the tickets at a very short notice.

I tried three days to get Ella ticket from here but they don‚Äôt have tickets for first class at all. In second class you may not get the seats. I took the reverse route and I went to Ella and travelled back to Nanu Oya to enjoy that dream train journey:

This is the station from where the most famous train leaves with a destination to Ella. The train is a simple one with no jing-bang to talk about. As our travel agent did not brief us properly, we were dropped at the station just in time. When the train arrived, we hustled ourselves in a crowded coach and stood for almost 2 hours from the overall 2.5 hrs of the journey. No ventilation. No proper fans. Seeing the mountain views were definitely not helping us change our mood. There is a reserved coach in the train, which I saw on de-boarding the train. Either ways, the views were not at all something that we couldn't get elsewhere in SL or even in India. Remember, that from Nuwara to Kandy - it is a road-ride through awesome tea plantations. Do not waste time and money here.

The train ride is over-rated and not as scenic as advertised. There's really nothing much to be seen except tea plantations (which is almost everywhere, nothing significant or Instagram worthy). The train station dated back to British times and was extremely run down with worn out timber sleepers. I am not sure how safe the trains will be. Inside the platform 'cafe' was a plaque which stated that the catering service was taken over on 1st Jan 1969. The trains ran on diesel and equally ill-maintained. The first class cabin had a distinct smell and 'flavour'. I would say its first class till the early 70s, its no different from 3rd class cabin now. Save your money and hire a van or car. There was nothing worth taking photos of, well perhaps the back of the seat...

Following are the train fares to Nanu Oya railway station from Kandy railway station: Inter-City Exp [1st Class AC ‚Äì Reserved] ‚Äì LKR 500 Inter-City Exp [2nd Class ‚Äì Reserved] ‚Äì LKR 350 Inter-City Exp [2nd Class ‚Äì Unreserved] ‚Äì LKR 160 Inter-City Exp [3rd Class ‚Äì Unreserved] ‚Äì LKR 90

The 7 hour long train ride from Kandy to Ella is said to be the most beautiful train ride in the world and I wouldn‚Äôt disagree. Our red train went through mountains, villages, beautiful tea estates and the longest tunnels that I‚Äôve seen so far. While locals and tea pluckers smiled and waved at passengers from the passing train to wish them a happy journey, passengers cheering together everytime the train entered a tunnel made the ride even more entertaining. Striking this off my bucket list. Note: The trains are packed and it‚Äôs difficult to get a window seat, you might even have to stand for hours before you get one.

Srilankan most famous train üöû leaves from Nanu Oya station (Nuwara Elya, heart of the Tea Country) with destination  Ella (and farther). May I also share my impressions with you, after the 3h30 journey ? a) despite what you are going to read on travel magazines articles/blogs, the whole ride on train is as scenic as any other through mountain landscapes. I think it's a bit overrated and that won't impress you so much. b) as an alternative, and in order to experience exclusively the best part of it, I would opt for the very short "Demodara loop" (6 kms long; cost of the ticket 10 LKR = ~0,05‚Ç¨). So catch the train directly in Ella, take a seat on the left side of the carriage/coach and get off at the next station (Demodara itself). You will enjoy the view passing on the NineArchBridge, while being greeted by hundreds of persons too. üòä
For the best train journeys in Sri Lanka. It is an old station, nothing flash, however, ticks the boxes, has a waiting room for foreigners, with nice (couches) seating and clean washrooms/toilets.

Ella to Nanu oya (3hrs) Then lunch at Nuwara eliya and visit a Tea Plantation en route to Kandy. Amazing train journey from Ella to Nanu Oya. Best to go in the second class compartment where you can peak out of the carriage doors to take some amazing photos of the train. You get vendors on the train selling hot roasted peanuts coated in salt and chilli - these are amazing. You also get fried snacks made of lentils which were superb. There is only one place to lunch in Nuwara Eliya and that‚Äôs Salmiya‚Äôs Italian Restuarant. It‚Äôs a small cafe tucked up a side road. Best pizzas ever. Really thin crust. Salmiya is an amazing host. Thank you for feeding all 24 of us. Salmiya did not even panic when we all turned up - took our orders and started rolling pizza dough. Her two assistants did all the chopping of fresh vegetables and herbs / washing plates etc - thank you to them too. I felt very sorry for the several back packers who arrived just after we placed our order as they would have had a very long wait! Then onwards to Kandy on the coach.
A place you should see and come out from the station to see the nuwaraeliya. From here only you can go for a good view to Ella or towards kandy. Very special to everyone.

As soon as the train arrived, I started to ask myself why would we do this ? The train was 1h30min late, when it stopped, people inside can‚Äôt even get off, it was crowded as hell. we got pushed onto the train, I can barely put both of my feet on the deck, and it smelled so bad, gross *100. It is supposed to be a two hour ride, which turned out to be 3 and half, there are no seats, you can imagine the rest.... Personally the whole situation just make it so difficult to really enjoy the view, even thought it is truly pretty. Would not do it again. will not recommend to anyone who are with kids.

We enjoyed the scenic train from Nanu Oya to Ella for the view. We had first class tickets but were disappointed that couples and families spread themselves over the cabin so they could get as many window seats as possible and then proceeded to go to sleep. Quite selfish but that's some people. Everything was quite rustic from the train carriages to the late time the train arrived. It may be charming but the state of the public toilets weren't. If you have a mobility issue I don't recommend the train.

There are many tourists struggling to get into the train. It is sad to say SLR is doing nothing to uplift standards of trains. The Minister of transport must be sleeping don't know the real ground situation. Why the railway authorities can't add few more carriage.

Our driver dropped us off at the station 30 minutes prior to the scheduled departure of the train to Ella.  We had attempted to purchase 1st class tickets but were told that those were sold out.  Only 3rd class tickets were left. The small drop-off area can only accommodate temporary parking.  You walk into the building to purchase the train tickets, then walk over to the correct platform.  One western toilet inside the "Foreigners Lounge" was located on one end of the platform.  As usual, bring your own toilet paper and hand wipes.  The other restrooms were for "2nd class and 3rd class" ticketholders. One side of the station is adjacent to a mountain, the other side has views of the tea plantations and farms.  Make sure you get on the trains quickly as there is a mad scramble to get seats since there are no assigned seats if you are not in first class.

An interesting journey in the observation car to Ella had us going backwards and we could see far more than if we were going forward. Some interesting points along the way but not one of the great railway journeys of the world. A very rural railway.
Very nice and clean trau station, walking venders sell you everything you need, the toilet is hiding in the restrooms.

Nanu Oya station is mostly known because it is at one end of the Nuwara Eliya - Ella, marginally interesting touristic train ride. The station itself is quite dirty and has nothing notable to offer except for a few stray dogs hanging around.

a good place to visit, more travellers visit this place, all ways  trains are there, very cool misty place, you can walk around the station and shoot photos, a beautiful place. and you can travell by old good trains.

You didn't visit Srilanka unless you have tried the ride to Ella by train, even tho we had a driver all the time, we went by train to experience the ride between tea plantation mountain and the no ending green valley. you can find the best view in all srilanka, hills mountains big valley, green is all over the place, a 2 hour ride that will take you breath away. Ask the guy who check your tickets to open the doors of the train so you can get a better view.

The train ride from Nanu Oya to Ella took around 3 hours and the train does not strictly follow the timetable. On our day there was a 45 minutes delay, which could post some issue if nature called as the station had only 1 functional toilet for foreigners, which as one could imagine the long queue in front. There are toilets for local if one could accept. The journey was quite scenic with the landscapes of tea plantation, cloud forests, and small towns and stations in between. We booked the first class cabin to secure the seats but this was by no means the luxury version. Though the cabin was air-conditioned but the best seats would be the open entrances, having direct views and better photo opportunities. However they were already occupied by fellow passengers from the start. We would not consider the train ride to be romantic as in other rides in the world but this is one unique experience in Sri Lanka with its natural beauties on display abundantly.
Nanu Oya is a village in Sri Lanka, named after the Nanu Oya river. It is located within Nuwara Eliya District in the Central Province and is situated approximately 8 km away from Nuwara Eliya

Als long als everyone says that you have to make the trainride Kandy to Ella, everyone will make it. We can absolutely not recommend this trainride. Sometimes in fact the views are nice, but never stunning. Go to Austria or Switzerland and you have the views you want to see. Than about the guard at the train, what a nasty guy. Sits alone in his huge compartment and in the meanwhile he is trying to get as much people in the train as possible standing shoulder to shoulder. Asking him to put people in his compartment is not the question, he wants to answer. He wants to stay alone in his compartment. Fire this wistle blowing idiot! Please do not go with this train in the high season, because you will be stacked in the train and see nothing of the views (that are not great, but nice), unless you have reserved seats in the first class. When you want to go in the high season and you have go second or third class, don't go by this train.

From Nanu Oya (closest station to Nuwara Eliya) to Ella the train ride takes approx. 2.5-3 hours. The scenery is as amazing as you probably have already read everywhere else. They weren‚Äôt lying. Every new turn will take your breath away. We took the 3pm from Nanu Oya and the train was not crowded at all. Unlike what we have anxiously anticipated there was no commotion during boarding and the train ride itself was calm and enjoyable. Our tickets were booked in advance via a local guide and we had both Air-conditioned first class and second-class reserved. Will definitely recommend the second class reserved option because you get wide open windows and doors (it didn‚Äôt rain during our journey). First class was filled with big families with small children so it was way busier and the AC was at a wishy-washy temperature. The train was not packed at all but during booking we were constantly being reminded tickets were selling out fast. So to avoid disappointment buy tickets in advance, we saw quite a few tourists being brought to the station by their guide just to buy tickets and leave. Will recommend this magical ride to everyone.

We went here only because we managed to get train tickets (3rd class) to Ella and the experience was amazing. The station itself was ok. We didn‚Äôt experience any issue with anyone. It was very quiet outside the station and on the platform waiting for the train there were many school kids laughing and asking us for sweets. Even the stray dogs were friendly. Facilities were good with a foreigner waiting room and a restaurant blasting out Indian music which was fun. The train was late but it‚Äôs wasn‚Äôt a problem as we weren‚Äôt in a rush. I would recommend (if you can get tickets) starting your journey from Nanu Oya as from the start of the journey the train goes through some wonderful tea plantation areas. If you go third class (also second class) the windows and doors are open so you get to really experience the outside in and you can take the iconic train photo when the train rolls around the hillside. Magical!!! Also third class was clean, comfortable and at least when we went empty so it was such an enjoyable experience.

Nanu Oya Railway Station is the nearest last stop railway station to Nuwara Eliya. So it is advisable for the foreign travelers who are on budget trip to Nuwara Eliya should be aware of the people (Guides & Tuk Tuk Drivers) on your arrival at the station. after passing the ticket counter there are several guides and Tuk Tuk drivers try to give you offers for the hotel reservations and transport to Nuwara Eliya. Most likely you will get disappointment if you accept there offers because most of them provide unclean and unfair hotels. They'll keep following you until you reach the main road which is approxiamtely 100m from the station. So it is best to take Tuk Tuk parked next to the main road. however they'll charge double for the foreign tourists but it is much cheaper than the Tuk Tuk guys parked next to the station. But the better option is to travel by bus from Nanu Oya to Nuwara Eliya for much cheaper. It's better if you ask people out there from bus time and the bus stop. Most of them will try to change your mind to take Tuk Tuk to Nuwara Eliya. Never seek any guide from Tuk Tuk guys. It's better if you ask from any Pedestrians out there. Learning to Bargain is too a great experience if you try. Some guides or Tuk Tuk Guys will try to overcharge after all the services are done. If they do so warn them that you are going to call the police. Then they will leave after swearing some beautiful words at you. If they don't, just call the police and inform them.

This is an important Railway station as it carries travellers to all the prominent hill country towns.    The Station has now been modernised and is worth a visit to admire the surroundings and also to take a ride in the local train.   It also has a Kiosk for hot drinks and tasty local bites
